docs.lead_paragraph: A number of small, private rescue funds have been lending a hand to a group that is definitely not in the too-big-to-fail camp: writers, artists and other creative types.

headline.seo: Artists’ Rescue Funds Can Help in Times of Crisis
headline.main: It’s Not Billions, but It Can Help Rescue an Artist
headline.print_headline: It’s Not Billions, But It Can Help Rescue an Artist

docs.abstract: Number of small, private rescue funds are financially helping some writers, artists and other creative types; run of bad luck can mean financial disaster for many artists, who are often self-employed; almost two million artists of various types are in the labor force.
docs.snippet: A number of small, private rescue funds have been lending a hand to a group that is definitely not in the too-big-to-fail camp: writers, artists and other creative types.

headline.print_headline: Don’t Like the Movie? Let’s Talk About It

docs.lead_paragraph: In the West, a new informal economy is in the making - a peculiar byproduct of the digital revolution that has freelancers doing tasks rather than workers holding jobs.

docs.lead_paragraph: Friday’s weak employment report was a potential turning point, focusing new attention on the economic implications of the partisan standoff over tax and spending policy.

headline.seo: Weak Job Growth Could Alter Presidential Campaign
headline.main: Slowdown in Growth Could Reshape Fight for Presidency
headline.print_headline: Sag in Economy Could Reshape ’12 Campaigns

docs.abstract: Weak employment report has the potential to reshape the presidential campaign, lifting Mitt Romney’s efforts to focus the race on Pres Obama’s handling of the economy and making it harder for Democrats to define Romney on their terms; signs of a slowdown place new attention on the implications of the Congressional standoff over tax and spending policy.
docs.snippet: Friday’s weak employment report was a potential turning point, focusing new attention on the economic implications of the partisan standoff over tax and spending policy.

byline.contributor: Jonathan Weisman reported from Washington and Mark Landler from Golden Valley, Minn. Michael D. Shear contributed reporting from Washington.
byline.original: By JONATHAN WEISMAN and MARK LANDLER

docs.lead_paragraph: It is heartening that after six weeks of silence and spirited discussion, American nuns are pushing back against the Vatican’s unjustified attack on their fidelity.

headline.seo: When in Rome, Speak Up for Reality
headline.main: When in Rome, Speak Up for Reality
headline.print_headline: When in Rome, Speak Up for Reality

docs.abstract: Editorial cheers the spirited defense put forward by the Leadership Conference of Women Religious, the largest and most influential group of Catholic nuns in the United States, six weeks after the Vatican's unjustified attack on their fidelity; holds that the nuns are asking for nothing more than an opportunity to confer with Vatican officials about some basic issues of gender equality in the church.
docs.snippet: It is heartening that after six weeks of silence and spirited discussion, American nuns are pushing back against the Vatican’s unjustified attack on their fidelity.

docs.lead_paragraph: General Motors will seek to cut $26 billion in pension obligations through changes in payments to retired white-collar workers.

headline.seo: G.M. to Use Buyouts to Cut Pension Obligations
headline.main: G.M. Plans Big Buyouts for Retirees in Pension
headline.print_headline: G.M. Plans Big Buyouts For Retirees In Pension

docs.abstract: General Motors announces that it will offer lump-sum payments to thousands of white-collar retirees to reduce its pension obligations, which are the biggest in the nation; will also pay Prudential Insurance to take over its pension payments to other retirees.
docs.snippet: General Motors will seek to cut $26 billion in pension obligations through changes in payments to retired white-collar workers.

byline.original: By BILL VLASIC and MARY WILLIAMS WALSH
By LIZ GERECITANO AND SUNITA REDDY

docs.lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (Cooking) THE CULINARY ADVENTURES OF BARON AMBROSIA Some people call Baron Ambrosia, the alter ego of the Bronx filmmaker Justin Fornal (above left, with a chef), ''the Ali G of food,'' a reference to the Sacha Baron Cohen character. He prefers to call himself a ''quaffer of culinary consciousness.'' Along with a camerman, he documents New York's ethnic pockets and their cuisines for his video podcast ''Underbelly NYC'' and his public-access show, ''Bronx Flavor.'' In this new series Mr. Fornal expands his horizons to places like Bridgeport, Conn., where, treasure map in hand, he follows in the footsteps of the showman P. T. Barnum, who was the city's mayor in 1875, and samples Peruvian ceviche, Haitian oxtail and Jamaican jerk chicken along the way. 7:35 A.M. (Cinemax) TOM JONES (1963) Albert Finney stars as an 18th-century English foundling turned Casanova in Tony Richardson's Academy Award-winning adaptation of the classic novel by Henry Fielding. Susannah York is Sophie, the passionate daughter of the blue-blooded Squire Western (Hugh Griffith), and the woman Tom hopes to wed -- through her father has other plans. Writing in The New York Times, Bosley Crowther called the film ''surely one of the wildest, bawdiest and funniest comedies that a refreshingly agile filmmaker has ever brought to the screen.''
